takeaway.headline: Teach baseline AI literacy for all students, then add role-based depth.
takeaway.subhead: Job postings show AI skills spreading beyond tech roles, and the most valuable skills differ by job family, discipline, and risk context.

coreSkills.desc: Limits, failure modes, verification habits, and when not to use AI.

coreSkills.title: Prompting + iteration
coreSkills.desc: Clear constraints, examples, critique loops, and evaluation criteria.

coreSkills.title: Data literacy
coreSkills.desc: Data quality, privacy basics, measurement, and experimentation mindset.

coreSkills.desc: Bias, privacy/security, transparency, and human oversight.

aiMentionsTrend.title: AI mentions in job postings are rising
aiMentionsTrend.method: Share of Indeed postings mentioning AI-related terms by month.

2020.headline: AI mentions were niche in 2020
2020.interpretation: Only a small share of postings included AI skills, concentrated in specialist roles.
2020.whyItMatters: Early baselines help institutions explain how quickly employer demand has shifted.
implications: Legacy curricula likely underprepare students for current AI-enabled work.
Skills diffusion can be tracked over time to update programs.
2020.teachingFocus: Introduce baseline AI literacy in first-year and core courses.

2021.headline: Demand started accelerating
2021.interpretation: Postings mentioning AI increased as employers tested automation and augmentation use cases.
2021.whyItMatters: Programs can use this period to show AI demand is not a short-lived spike.
implications: Employers began expecting practical tool familiarity.
Cross-functional teams started sharing AI-related responsibilities.
2021.teachingFocus: Teach prompting and verification routines in applied assignments.

2022.headline: Temporary dip before a larger expansion
2022.interpretation: Mentions softened briefly, then resumed strong growth as new tools matured.
2022.whyItMatters: Leaders should avoid overreacting to single-year fluctuations.
implications: Trend direction matters more than one-period volatility.
Strategic curriculum change should be multi-year.
2022.teachingFocus: Build durable foundations in data literacy and critical evaluation.

2023.headline: Mainstream adoption phase begins
2023.interpretation: AI mentions rebounded as organizations scaled copilots and assistant workflows.
2023.whyItMatters: Students increasingly compete in markets where AI-enabled productivity is expected.
implications: Hiring managers may differentiate candidates by practical AI fluency.
Evidence-based portfolio work becomes more valuable.
2023.teachingFocus: Embed AI-supported project work in capstones and internships.

2024.headline: Strong broad-based growth
2024.interpretation: Mentions rose further as adoption expanded beyond early-adopter teams.
2024.whyItMatters: AI readiness is now a general employability issue, not just a technical specialty.
implications: All departments should articulate AI learning outcomes.
Faculty development becomes a strategic priority.
2024.teachingFocus: Create discipline-specific AI use policies and exemplar assignments.

Dec 2025.headline: AI mentions reached 4.2% in Dec 2025
Dec 2025.interpretation: The highest point in this series indicates sustained employer interest in AI capabilities.
Dec 2025.whyItMatters: Executive planning should treat AI skills as core workforce readiness outcomes.
implications: Program reviews should map outcomes to AI-enabled competencies.
Career services can coach students on AI evidence in resumes and interviews.
Dec 2025.teachingFocus: Prioritize assessment rubrics that evaluate responsible and effective AI use.

aiMentionsByFamily.title: AI mentions by job family
aiMentionsByFamily.method: Share of postings mentioning AI by occupational family in Dec 2025.

Data & Analytics.headline: Data & Analytics leads AI demand
Data & Analytics.interpretation: AI skills are deeply embedded in analytic, reporting, and decision-support workflows.
Data & Analytics.whyItMatters: Students entering data-adjacent roles need more than basic prompting—they need model and data judgment.
implications: Employers expect experimentation, validation, and communication of AI outputs.
Portfolio projects should demonstrate reproducible analysis with AI tooling.
Data & Analytics.teachingFocus: Expand advanced analytics labs with evaluation and governance checkpoints.

Marketing.headline: Marketing shows strong practical AI adoption
Marketing.interpretation: Teams use AI for ideation, content generation, testing, and audience analysis.
Marketing.whyItMatters: Graduates need workflow fluency plus brand-safe review processes.
implications: Human-in-the-loop editing remains essential.
Measurement literacy is needed to validate campaign outcomes.
Marketing.teachingFocus: Teach prompt libraries, A/B testing, and quality controls for creative work.

Human Resources.headline: HR adoption is meaningful and rising
Human Resources.interpretation: AI appears in recruiting, policy drafting, and employee support workflows.
Human Resources.whyItMatters: These use cases are high-impact and can introduce fairness or privacy risk.
implications: Students need strong Responsible AI and compliance habits.
Policy transparency and audit trails are critical in people operations.
Human Resources.teachingFocus: Include bias checks, documentation templates, and escalation protocols.

aiOutsideITShare.title: AI demand extends beyond IT/CS
aiOutsideITShare.method: Share of AI-skill postings inside vs outside IT and computer science families.

Outside IT/CS.headline: Most AI demand is now outside IT/CS
Outside IT/CS.interpretation: AI capabilities are diffusing into business, health, education, and creative domains.
Outside IT/CS.whyItMatters: Institution-wide strategy is required; AI readiness cannot sit only in technical departments.
implications: General education and major courses should include AI-enabled work.
Cross-disciplinary faculty communities of practice can accelerate adoption.
Outside IT/CS.teachingFocus: Scale discipline-specific AI assignments and assessment criteria.

IT/CS.headline: IT/CS remains a major AI talent engine
IT/CS.interpretation: Technical programs still supply critical builder and governance expertise.
IT/CS.whyItMatters: Institutions need both broad literacy and deep specialist pathways.
implications: Balance advanced technical tracks with campus-wide AI fluency.
Promote collaboration between technical and non-technical disciplines.
IT/CS.teachingFocus: Strengthen engineering tracks in evaluation, safety, and deployment.
